Summary Motivated and creative young researcher interested in all areas of science particularly semiconductor physics, astrophysics, geophysics and nuclear science. My experience of working at Intel, Inc. (Ireland), CERN (Switzerland), Linköping University (Sweden) and Dublin City University (Ireland) has shown me the class and organisation required to work in modern research and engineering.  
 
I have formed long-lasting relationships with scientists and non-scientists alike from various institutions in my roles and the work I've performed has lead to several publications in high impact peer-reviewed scientific journals. 
 
I have also presented my work many times to the scientific community and the broader public, both as a speaker and at poster sessions/competitions, particularly at MRS Boston (a major semiconductor science conference) where I was a speaker. 
 
I am interested in scientific outreach and communication and have an established record of successfully presenting my work to the scientific and broader community. I have received several awards for my presentations, both as a speaker and for poster presentations. I have also acted as a reviewer for publications submitted to peer-reviewed journals such as Chemical Physics Letters and Journal of Applied Physics. 
 
I was a volunteer at the very successful Festival of Curiosity event in Dublin, Ireland in 2013 and 2014 which attracted more than 30,000 attendees. I also volunteered at the BT Young Scientist Competition in 2013 working at the Institute of Physics exhibit showcasing physics to young and old visitors. Experience Process Engineer Intel Corporation September 2014  – Present (1 year) Ireland Graduate Process Engineer responsible for dry etch processing with Intel Ireland, Ltd. 
 
Responsible for the quality of the material processed on our equipment which form an integral component in the production of semiconductor wafers. This requires a precise understanding of tool-specific process techniques and a broader understanding of our role within the production environment. 
 
Clear and effective communication to stakeholders is required at all stages of production and in this role that includes the communication of complex technical data obtained from frequent monitoring of tool behaviour and activities. Project Coordinator University College Dublin (UCD) Job Vacancies April 2014  –  May 2014  (2 months) Ireland As Project Coordinator for the Science Foundation Ireland (SFI) Centres funding call in University College Dublin I was involved in coordinating academic and industry applicants for two separate proposals. Each of the two proposals was worth in the region of €30 million.  
 
In this role I worked closely with program managers at UCD Research to ensure accurate and timely delivery of proposals. This required strong communication and coordination skills to work within a precise framework. Postdoctoral Researcher Linköping University September 2013  –  February 2014  (6 months) linkoping, sweden As a PostDoctoral Researcher in the Functional Electronic Materials group at Linköping University I was responsible for measuring and characterising semiconductor materials.  
 
These materials (for example, the wide bandgap semiconductor ZnO) are of critical interest to emerging fields such as spintronics and solid state lighting. 
 
Measurements are performed at various temperatures by exciting the electrons in the valence band of the semiconductor into the conduction band. From there the electron can couple with a hole, forming an exciton. The behaviour of this exciton can reveal a great deal of information about the fundamental properties of the material. 
 
I specialise in photoluminescence, magneto-optics, Raman spectroscopy and time-resolved measurements. Semiconductor physicist CERN February 2009  –  January 2014  (5 years) Switzerland My PhD work involved many hours spent working at the ISOLDE isotope separator facility at CERN, Geneva. Samples (mostly ZnO) were implanted with radioactive elements and the sample emission monitored over time as the radioactive element decayed into its daughter isotopes. PhD Student Dublin City University November 2008  –  December 2012  (4 years 2 months) Ireland My PhD work has encompassed many hours spent teaching eager undergraduates the wonders of physics! Unfortunately it's not always so straight-forward to teach the wonders of physics...
